On Monday 03 March 2003 17:31, S. Alexander Jacobson wrote:
> I know that I was the one advocating capabilities,
> but I think the examples show how difficult they
> are to use in real life.

You're a true contrarian. ;)

Capabilities are actually very easy to use "in real life" and much
easier to use than ACLs. ACLs are difficult to manage and open you
up to all sorts of subtle security vulnerabilities. If you've ever
written code that uses ACLs, chances are you've written code that
is vulnerable to a Confused Deputy attack.

> If I am looking at a page with my January
> bank account history, I would like some way to
> navigate back to the main menu....

There are solutions to this, but first I'll point out that this
issue doesn't apply to software programs.  "Web services" address
program to program communication. Programs have a stack and a heap
to help them keep track of what they've got and what they're
doing. A program doesn't "navigate back", it just dereferences a
variable.

It's also easy to implement "navigate back" from within a web
browser interface to the application. The simplest answer is just:
"Use the 'back' button to navigate 'back'.". A step up from there
is using frames. You can keep your main menu in a small frame
along the left or top of the screen. The main menu is then always
accessible to the user. If you don't like frames, you can use XSLT
to build a composite page on the server. The XSLT code can suck in
XML from a variety of capability URLs and then display a composite
page that includes navigation tools.

Everything really is at your fingertips. Having the security model
integrated right into the programming model really simplifies
things. Imagine building an application that aggregates
information from a bunch of different applications. With a
capability-based security model, you just suck in the XML and do
your thing. In an ACL model, you've got the additional headache of
managing credentials and authentication protocols with each
different application.

> If I am the WSJ, how do I restrict access while
> at the same time allow users to refer to the same
> document?

You were the one who suggested this design, not me. This is now
the third time that I have said that this is a bad idea. You would
not use the capability model to solve this problem.

There's a long explanation that I could go into on this, but I'll
just give you the punch line. The WSJ scenario is *not* an access
control problem, it is a DRM (Digital Restrictions Management)
problem. The capability model is used for solving access control
problems, not DRM problems.

Tyler
